clusters.title: Rage rooms: can smashing stuff up really help to relieve anger and stress?
clusters.neutral_headline: Rage Rooms: Can Smashing Stuff Relieve Anger and Stress?

items.title: Rage rooms: can smashing stuff up really help to relieve anger and stress?
items.standfirst: Venues promoting destruction as stress relief are appearing around the UK but experts – and our correspondent – are unsureIf you find it hard to count to 10 when anger bubbles up, a new trend offers a more hands-on approach. Rage rooms are cropping up across the UK, allowing punters to smash seven bells out of old TVs, plates and furniture.Such pay-to-destroy ventures are thought to have originated in Japan in 2008, but have since gone global. In the UK alone venues can be found in locations from Birmingham to Brighton, with many promoting destruction as a stress-relieving experience. Continue reading...

In the UK alone venues can be found in locations from Birmingham to Brighton, with many promoting destruction as a stress-relieving experience. Continue reading...

clusters.title: ‘It has made me live life more’: Jessie J on cancer, comebacks and cracking China
clusters.neutral_headline: Jessie J on Cancer, Comebacks, and Cracking China

items.title: ‘It has made me live life more’: Jessie J on cancer, comebacks and cracking China
items.standfirst: Endometriosis, miscarriage, failed relationships, suicide and gaslighting … they are all laid bare on the singer-writer’s new album. But just as she finished recording it, she got a shock diagnosis. She explains why it’s made her determined to be in the momentYou couldn’t make it up, Jessie J says. There she was preparing for her first album release in eight years, ecstatically in love with her newish partner, and finally the mother of a toddler having struggled to conceive for a decade, on top of the world. Then in March she was diagnosed with breast cancer.The singer-songwriter, real name Jessica Cornish, is famous for telling it as it is. The album, Don’t Tease Me With a Good Time, was supposed to be an open book, dealing with every ounce of devastation she’d experienced since she last recorded music (endometriosis, miscarriage, failed relationships, gaslighting, suicide) with typical candour. The first single, No Secrets, was released in April. But by then there was a mighty secret. The cancer. Then second single, Living My Best Life, came out in May and Cornish was giving interviews about how she was living her best life, while still secretly living with breast cancer. A month later she went public, and in early July she had a mastectomy. Continue reading...
items.content: Endometriosis, miscarriage, failed relationships, suicide and gaslighting … they are all laid bare on the singer-writer’s new album. But just as she finished recording it, she got a shock diagnosis. She explains why it’s made her determined to be in the momentYou couldn’t make it up, Jessie J says. There she was preparing for her first album release in eight years, ecstatically in love with her newish partner, and finally the mother of a toddler having struggled to conceive for a decade, on top of the world. Then in March she was diagnosed with breast cancer.The singer-songwriter, real name Jessica Cornish, is famous for telling it as it is. The album, Don’t Tease Me With a Good Time, was supposed to be an open book, dealing with every ounce of devastation she’d experienced since she last recorded music (endometriosis, miscarriage, failed relationships, gaslighting, suicide) with typical candour. The first single, No Secrets, was released in April. But by then there was a mighty secret. The cancer. Then second single, Living My Best Life, came out in May and Cornish was giving interviews about how she was living her best life, while still secretly living with breast cancer. A month later she went public, and in early July she had a mastectomy. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Jessie J discusses her cancer diagnosis and its impact on her life.
The singer-songwriter was diagnosed with breast cancer after preparing for an album release.
The album deals with personal struggles including endometriosis and failed relationships.
Jessie J had a mastectomy after going public with her diagnosis.
The article explores her determination to live in the moment.

clusters.title: Brain damage, blindness and death: the global trail of trauma left by methanol-laced alcohol
clusters.neutral_headline: Methanol-Laced Alcohol: Global Trauma Trail

items.title: Brain damage, blindness and death: the global trail of trauma left by methanol-laced alcohol
items.standfirst: Methanol, a cheap relative of ethanol, is entering the supply chain, causing thousands of deaths around the worldFor Bethany Clarke, poison tasted like nothing. There was no bitter aftertaste, no astringent sting at the back of the tongue. If anything, she thought in passing, the free shots she and her friends were drinking at a hostel bar in Laos had probably been watered down – she wasn’t detecting a strong vodka flavour through the veil of Sprite she had mixed it with.All in all, Clarke remembers drinking about five of those shots, sitting with her best friend, Simone White, and a crowd of others at the hostel’s happy hour. CCTV footage shows the group laughing in the warm air of the open bar in the town of Vang Vieng, green and red lights dancing over their shoulders. Continue reading...
items.content: Methanol, a cheap relative of ethanol, is entering the supply chain, causing thousands of deaths around the worldFor Bethany Clarke, poison tasted like nothing. There was no bitter aftertaste, no astringent sting at the back of the tongue. If anything, she thought in passing, the free shots she and her friends were drinking at a hostel bar in Laos had probably been watered down – she wasn’t detecting a strong vodka flavour through the veil of Sprite she had mixed it with.All in all, Clarke remembers drinking about five of those shots, sitting with her best friend, Simone White, and a crowd of others at the hostel’s happy hour. CCTV footage shows the group laughing in the warm air of the open bar in the town of Vang Vieng, green and red lights dancing over their shoulders. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Methanol-laced alcohol is causing deaths worldwide.
Methanol is a cheaper, more dangerous alternative to ethanol.
The article details the experiences of those affected by methanol poisoning.
The article describes the effects of methanol poisoning, including blindness.
The article highlights the global impact of contaminated alcohol.

clusters.title: The loss of access to and respect for autonomous midwifery is tragic | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Midwifery Access and Respect Loss is Tragic

items.title: The loss of access to and respect for autonomous midwifery is tragic | Letters
items.standfirst: A concerned NHS midwife responds to an article about the Free Birth SocietyI’m an NHS midwife, despairing over your article (Influencers made millions pushing ‘wild’ births – now the Free Birth Society is linked to baby deaths around the world, 22 November). My key frustration, though, is how, as with any successful charlatanism, there is truth and real fear being exploited: medical overreach blights lives, women can and should trust their bodies, and a healthy body rarely grows a baby it can’t birth.However, physiology is not a perfected endpoint. Evolution continues with genetic variation spreading through a population by “survival of the fittest”. In the brutal “wild”, the least “well-adapted” (whether by health or circumstance) do not survive. Human beings, however, don’t like those odds. Medical intervention, yes, but a body of life-saving social knowledge has been passed down since language began, towards facilitating successful birth. Continue reading...
items.content: A concerned NHS midwife responds to an article about the Free Birth SocietyI’m an NHS midwife, despairing over your article (Influencers made millions pushing ‘wild’ births – now the Free Birth Society is linked to baby deaths around the world, 22 November). My key frustration, though, is how, as with any successful charlatanism, there is truth and real fear being exploited: medical overreach blights lives, women can and should trust their bodies, and a healthy body rarely grows a baby it can’t birth.However, physiology is not a perfected endpoint. Evolution continues with genetic variation spreading through a population by “survival of the fittest”. In the brutal “wild”, the least “well-adapted” (whether by health or circumstance) do not survive. Human beings, however, don’t like those odds. Medical intervention, yes, but a body of life-saving social knowledge has been passed down since language began, towards facilitating successful birth. Continue reading...

ai_summary: An NHS midwife responds to an article about the Free Birth Society.
The author expresses frustration with the exploitation of fear.
The author emphasizes the importance of medical intervention.
The author highlights the role of medical knowledge in childbirth.
The author is concerned about the loss of autonomous midwifery.

clusters.title: Was JMW Turner’s mother really ‘mentally ill’? | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Turner's Mother's Mental Health Questioned

items.title: Was JMW Turner’s mother really ‘mentally ill’? | Letter
items.standfirst: It seems likely the artist’s family wanted to get rid of a woman who was just difficult to get along with, writes Helen JamesJMW Turner mother’s died when she was 29, when he was busy preparing for and opening his first public exhibition, and her “mental illness”, referred to in your review of the BBC Two documentary Turner: The Secret Sketchbooks (19 November), should be described as “purported”.We only have the testimony provided by the actions of her husband and son, who sent her to a lunatic asylum designed for paupers, when they were in fact not poor and could have accommodated her in a better environment with better care, and thereby lengthened her life. Continue reading...
items.content: It seems likely the artist’s family wanted to get rid of a woman who was just difficult to get along with, writes Helen JamesJMW Turner mother’s died when she was 29, when he was busy preparing for and opening his first public exhibition, and her “mental illness”, referred to in your review of the BBC Two documentary Turner: The Secret Sketchbooks (19 November), should be described as “purported”.We only have the testimony provided by the actions of her husband and son, who sent her to a lunatic asylum designed for paupers, when they were in fact not poor and could have accommodated her in a better environment with better care, and thereby lengthened her life. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A letter questions the description of JMW Turner's mother's mental illness.
The author suggests the family may have wanted to remove her.
The mother was sent to a pauper's asylum.
The author argues for a more nuanced understanding of the situation.
The letter responds to a review of a BBC documentary.

clusters.title: Expert panel advises against prostate cancer screening for most men in UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Expert Panel Recommends Against Prostate Cancer Screening in UK

items.title: Expert panel advises against prostate cancer screening for most men in UK
items.standfirst: Charities express ‘deep disappointment’ as government advisers find harms of screening all men would outweigh benefitsProstate cancer screening should not be made available to the vast majority of men across the UK, a panel of expert government health advisers has said, to the “deep disappointment” of several charities and campaigners.The UK National Screening Committee (UKNSC) has instead recommended that there should be a targeted screening programme for men with a confirmed BRCA1 or BRCA2 faulty gene variant, which means they are more at risk of faster growing and aggressive cancers at an earlier age. Men in that category could be screened every two years between the ages of 45 and 61, they said. Continue reading...
items.content: Charities express ‘deep disappointment’ as government advisers find harms of screening all men would outweigh benefitsProstate cancer screening should not be made available to the vast majority of men across the UK, a panel of expert government health advisers has said, to the “deep disappointment” of several charities and campaigners.The UK National Screening Committee (UKNSC) has instead recommended that there should be a targeted screening programme for men with a confirmed BRCA1 or BRCA2 faulty gene variant, which means they are more at risk of faster growing and aggressive cancers at an earlier age. Men in that category could be screened every two years between the ages of 45 and 61, they said. Continue reading...

ai_summary: UK health advisors recommend against prostate cancer screening for most men in the UK.
Targeted screening is advised for men with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene variants.
Men with the gene variants could be screened every two years between ages 45 and 61.
Charities expressed deep disappointment with the recommendation against widespread screening.
The recommendation aims to balance benefits and potential harms of screening.

clusters.title: How the beauty industry still profits from colonialism – video
clusters.neutral_headline: Beauty Industry Profits from Colonialism, Skin Lightening Concerns

items.title: How the beauty industry still profits from colonialism – video
items.standfirst: The skin-lightening industry is booming, while at the same time there has been a surge in cancers and irreversible skin damage among women of colour using unregulated products. But this is not a new story. The dangers of skin-lightening products have been well documented for years, so how is this still happening? Josh Toussaint-Strauss digs into the long history behind the practice of skin lightening, and how the beauty industry has used messaging rooted in classism and colonialism to sell its products, as well as investigating what unregulated products are doing to the skinHow the colonial legacy has created a toxic beauty industryHow skin-lightening products are linked to cancer in black African women Continue reading...
items.content: The skin-lightening industry is booming, while at the same time there has been a surge in cancers and irreversible skin damage among women of colour using unregulated products. But this is not a new story. The dangers of skin-lightening products have been well documented for years, so how is this still happening? Josh Toussaint-Strauss digs into the long history behind the practice of skin lightening, and how the beauty industry has used messaging rooted in classism and colonialism to sell its products, as well as investigating what unregulated products are doing to the skinHow the colonial legacy has created a toxic beauty industryHow skin-lightening products are linked to cancer in black African women Continue reading...

ai_summary: The skin-lightening industry is experiencing a boom, despite known health risks.
Unregulated skin-lightening products are linked to cancers and skin damage.
The beauty industry uses messaging rooted in classism and colonialism.
The article explores the historical context of skin lightening practices.
It investigates the impact of unregulated products on the skin.

clusters.title: FDA poised to kill proposal that would require asbestos testing for cosmetics
clusters.neutral_headline: FDA Poised to Drop Asbestos Testing Rule for Cosmetics

items.title: FDA poised to kill proposal that would require asbestos testing for cosmetics
items.standfirst: RFK Jr signed order withdrawing rule that would mandate testing for the cancer-linked toxin in talc-based makeupThe Food and Drug Administration is poised to kill a proposed rule that would require testing for toxic asbestos in talc-based cosmetics, a problem that has been linked to cancer.Talc is widely used, including in cosmetics, food, medication and personal care products. The order was signed by health secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr, leader of the “Make America healthy again” (Maha) movement. Continue reading...
items.content: RFK Jr signed order withdrawing rule that would mandate testing for the cancer-linked toxin in talc-based makeupThe Food and Drug Administration is poised to kill a proposed rule that would require testing for toxic asbestos in talc-based cosmetics, a problem that has been linked to cancer.Talc is widely used, including in cosmetics, food, medication and personal care products. The order was signed by health secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr, leader of the “Make America healthy again” (Maha) movement. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The FDA is set to withdraw a rule requiring asbestos testing in talc-based cosmetics.
The proposed rule aimed to address cancer risks associated with asbestos exposure.
Robert F Kennedy Jr signed the order to withdraw the testing mandate.
Talc is used in cosmetics, food, medication, and personal care products.
The decision follows concerns about the cancer-linked toxin in talc.
